item.title: AboutMe
item.description:
permalink

I'm a happy programmer living in Beijing, China. My real name is Zhang Yichun, or 章亦春 in Chinese.

I'm currently working as a Technical Expert for the Quantum Team in Taobao.com's Data Product & Platform department. I designed and implemented the underlying architecture of the front-end and middle-layer of the LineZing analytic application for Taobao.com's sellers.

The front-end application of LineZing is written completely in JavaScript and running in end user's web browser just like Gmail. The middle-layer is powered by ngx_openresty developed by ourselves, a massively enhanced version of nginx that serves as a full-fledged web app stack.

We've developed dozens of nginx C modules including ngx_echo, ngx_headers_more, ngx_lua, ngx_drizzle, and ngx_redis2, and opensourced them with the permission from the company. We do have users worldwide, including Taobao, Facebook, and Qunar.com.

I'm also leading the automated testing practices within the team, mainly with Perl 5.

In Taobao, I've created the (proprietary) LZSQL domain-spefic language to simplify the business logic coding involved in developing web services for data products. The LZSQL compiler is written in Perl 5 and emits compact Lua code. It has built-in capabilities to abstract distributed mysql cluster details and to perform complex SQL query optimizations that cannot be done by MySQL.

Prior to joining Taobao.com, I was working as a Senior Software Developer in Yahoo! China's Search Tech. Department.

While in Yahoo! China, I created OpenResty.pm to provide a generic service-oriented platform for the relavance search business, mainly written in Perl 5 & Haskell.

I designed and implemented Gecko/WebKit-powered intelligent webpage crawlers and extractors based on our own vision analysis and expert systems, main written in Perl 5 & C++. See my slides for details (use the arrow keys on your keyboard to switch pages).

As my first $work project, I created the SearchAll Firefox extension that does side-by-side search engine comparison, mainly written in JavaScript, which is also approved by Mozilla.

item.title: Presentations
item.description:
permalink

Here goes a list of slides that I used in various opensource events and school lectures.

These slides are powered by the slides.htm slide-making engine based on AJAX.

Note: Please use the arrow keys or pageup/pagedown keys on your keyboard to switch pages.

Year 2010


Introduction to nginx.conf scripting


This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2010 April meeting and the Beijing OpenParty 2010 June event.

View in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/nginx-conf-scripting/

Recent developments in nginx.conf scripting


This talk was given at the Beijing OpenParty 2010 June event.

View in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/recent-dev-nginx-conf/

The state of the art of nginx.conf scripting


This talk was given at the ECUG 2010 event.

Watch the (Chinese-speech) video online: http://v.ku6.com/show/D00rqtnRwKzJdIsB.html

View the (English) slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/nginx-state-of-the-art/

Year 2009


A Firefox cluster driven by JavaScript, Perl, & PL/PgSQL


This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2009 Feb Meetup and Beijing OpenParty 2009 Feb event.

View the slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/BJPW200902/ffcluster.html

Introduction to our VDOM.pm & vdom-webkit cluster


Use vision information to do intelligent web scraping by rendering pages via a WebKit & VDOM cluster.

This talk was given at Beijing Perl Workshop 2009 and a meetup with Taobao.com's front-end engineers in the Hangzhou city.

View the slides in your browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/taobao-fe/vdomwebkit.html

A Tour of Perl Testing


This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2009 event.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/BJPW2009/perl-testing.html

Year 2008


Nifty web apps on an OpenResty


This talk was given at the D2 Frontend Technology event organized by Yahoo! China.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/openresty-d2/

OpenResty: Your Relational Cloud


OpenResty.pm is a general-purpose RESTful web service platform. In this talk I explained its origin, REST API, and its unusual applications.

This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2008 event and the Yahoo! China Engineer Tech. Salon.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/openresty-yes/

Year 2007


XUL::App - Jifty way of doing XUL


XUL::App is a nifty Firefox extension development framework based on Perl. It has a lot of parallels with Jifty. In particular, this framework allows you to build real-world modern Firefox extensions using Perl.

In this talk, I demonstrated how to use this framework to write a "hello, world" Firefox extension with I18N support in lines.

This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2008 event.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/xulapp/

Contribute to Pugs


Pugs is a Perl 6 compiler written in Haskell. In this talk, I introduced the Pugs project as well as my involvement in the automated testing work of the Perl 6 language to the PerlChina folks and encouraged people to contribute Pugs.

This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2007 event.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/contr_pugs/

Use UML::Class::Simple to generate simple UML class diagrams


UML::Class::Simple is my Perl CPAN module that can generate UML class diagrams automatically from arbitrary real-world Perl OO libraries.

This talk was given at the Beijing Perl Workshop 2007 event.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/umlclass/

Year 2006


Introduction to XClips


XClips is an expert system development language designed by myself, which is implemented atop NASA's CLIPS. This talk explains the appearance of the language and some details of its implementation and applications.

This talk was given as a lecture at the Jiangsu University.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/xclips/

The Art of Naming


This talk teaches the art of naming for programmers, using lots of examples from Perl 6, C/C++, Java, and other programming languages.

This talk was given as a lecture at the Jiangsu University.

View slides in your web browser:
  • http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/naming/
  • http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/naming/naming_recap.html

XML in the real world


This talk shows various interesting applications of XML in the real world. It also introduces some of my web scraping tools based on Perl 5.

This talk was given as a lecture at the Jiangsu University.

Functions and Methods


This lecture discusses functions and methods in Object-Oriented Programming (OOP). This is one of my series of lectures on OOP given at the Jiangsu University.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/func/

Design Patterns - Using FAST


This talk explains the design patterns used in the construction process of the FAST (Flowchart Abstract Syntax Tree transformer) program, which can convert a program described by a flowchart into a structural program.

This talk was given as a lecture at the Jiangsu University.

View slides in your web browser: http://agentzh.org/misc/slides/patterns/
